title: Cylinder Head - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.

The rubbing blades for the camshaft drive chain protrude from the crankcase such that removal of the head while in the frame is made extremely difficult and may lead to damage to the head, rubbing blades and frame.
Cylinder head remove links PB1 PJ1 PJZ
Camshaft Drive Chain Tensioner Blade and Rubbing Blade - Removal
To prevent the shims from becoming mixed, place the shims in a marked container. The shims must be refitted in their original positions.
Note the position of all shims so that they can be refitted in the same positions. Lift up the finger followers and remove the shims.
Release the fixings securing the right hand side of the cylinder head to the upper crankcase.
Cylinder head to upper crankcase fixings
Two of the cylinder head bolts are to be used with
Progressively release the cylinder head bolts in the order shown below.
Lightly tap the cylinder head with a rubber mallet to break the seal of the gasket.
Lift the head directly upwards until clear of the camshaft drive chain rubbing blades.
Note the position of the location dowels for installation.
The gasket between the barrel and the crankcase must also be replaced if the cylinder head has been removed.
Failure to replace the gasket may result in an engine oil leak between the barrel and crankcase.
To hold the barrel in position, fit
to the cylinder head and secure using two of the original bolts for the cylinder head.

search: Cylinder Head - Removal
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.

The rubbing blades for the camshaft drive chain protrude from the crankcase such that removal of the head while in the frame is made extremely difficult and may lead to damage to the head, rubbing blades and frame.
Perform the following operations:
Engine - Removal
Camshafts - Removal
Camshaft Drive Chain Tensioner Blade and Rubbing Blade - Removal
To prevent the shims from becoming mixed, place the shims in a marked container. The shims must be refitted in their original positions.
Note the position of all shims so that they can be refitted in the same positions. Lift up the finger followers and remove the shims.
Finger follower
Shim
Release the fixings securing the right hand side of the cylinder head to the upper crankcase.
Cylinder head to upper crankcase fixings
Two of the cylinder head bolts are to be used with
service tool T3880423
to secure the barrel.
Progressively release the cylinder head bolts in the order shown below.
Cylinder Head Bolt Release Sequence
Lightly tap the cylinder head with a rubber mallet to break the seal of the gasket.
Lift the head directly upwards until clear of the camshaft drive chain rubbing blades.
Note the position of the location dowels for installation.
Location dowels
The gasket between the barrel and the crankcase must also be replaced if the cylinder head has been removed.
Failure to replace the gasket may result in an engine oil leak between the barrel and crankcase.
To hold the barrel in position, fit
service tool T3880423
to the cylinder head and secure using two of the original bolts for the cylinder head.
Remove the barrel (see
Barrels - Removal
) and discard the gasket.
